evidence: it is expected to drop by a further 0.3 to 0.5 ph units (an additional doubling to tripling of today's post-industrial acid concentrations) by 2100 as the oceans absorb more anthropogenic co 2, the impacts being most severe for coral reefs and the southern ocean.

claim: marine life has nothing whatsoever to fear from ocean acidification.”
label: refutes
evidence: human activities affect marine life and marine habitats through overfishing, pollution, acidification and the introduction of invasive species.

claim: [ocean acidification was ] first referenced in a peer-reviewed study in nature in 2003
label: supports
evidence: a national research council study released in april 2010 likewise concluded that "the level of acid in the oceans is increasing at an unprecedented rate".

claim: “the jet stream forms a boundary between the cold north and the warmer south, but the lower temperature difference means the winds are now weaker.
label: supports
evidence: this in turn reduces the temperature gradient that drives jet stream winds, which may eventually cause the jet stream to become weaker and more variable in its course.

claim: this means the jet stream meanders more, with big loops bringing warm air to the frozen north and cold air into warmer southern climes.”
label: supports
evidence: according to the uk met office, the jet stream deviated[clarification needed] to the south (bringing cold air with it) as a result of unusual contrast between cold air in canada and mild winter temperatures in the united states.

claim: this “blocking” effect means extreme events can unfold.”

label: supports

claim: this means it is possible that by some yardsticks, 2016 will be declared as hot as 2015 or even slightly hotter – because el nino did not vanish until the middle of the year.

claim: the record warm years of 2015 and 2016 were primarily caused by the super el nino.’”

claim: scientists confirm a mass bleaching event on the great barrier reef this year has killed more corals than ever before, with more than two thirds destroyed across large swathes of the biodiverse site.
label: supports

claim: when water temperatures become too high, coral becomes stressed and expels the algae, which leave the coral a bleached white color.

claim: mass coral bleaching is a new phenomenon and was never observed before the 1980s as global warming ramped up.
label: supports

claim: even as sea ice in the arctic has seen a rapid and consistent decline over the past decade, its counterpart in the southern hemisphere has seen its extent increasing.”
label: supports

claim: skeptics have long pointed to ice gain in the southern hemisphere as evidence climate change wasn’t occurring, but scientists warned that it was caused by natural variations and circulations in the atmosphere.
label: disputed

claim: it “certainly puts the kibosh on everyone saying that antarctica’s ice is just going up and up,” meier said.

claim: for what appears to be the first time since scientists began keeping track, sea ice in the arctic and the antarctic are at record lows this time of year.

claim: “it’s far too early to tell if what we are seeing in the arctic, and now the antarctic, is a sharp shift towards warmer poles with less ice.
label: refutes

claim: temperatures in the arctic have soared recently, and scientists are struggling to explain exactly why.

claim: to make matters worse, the water temperatures in the arctic ocean are several degrees above average, which is an expected result of having less sea ice.

claim: “unlike genuine pollutants, carbon dioxide (co2) is an odorless, colorless gas.

claim: [co2] is also a greenhouse gas which helps maintain earth at a habitable temperature.
label: supports

claim: but observations, such as those on our co2 coalition website, show that increased co2 levels over the next century will cause modest and beneficial warming—perhaps as much as one degree celsius (1.8 degrees fahrenheit)

claim: the costs of emissions regulations, which will be paid by everyone, will be punishingly high and will provide no benefits to most people anywhere in the world.
label: disputed

claim: with more co2 in the atmosphere, the challenge [feeding 2.5 billion more people] can and will be met.

claim: “global warming and climate change, even if it is 100% caused by humans, is so slow that it cannot be observed by anyone in their lifetime.

claim: hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, droughts and other natural disasters have yet to show any obvious long-term change.”

claim: drought in the western u.s. pales in comparison to the mega-droughts tree rings tell us existed in centuries past.

claim: if a major hurricane is approaching with a predicted storm surge of 10-14 feet, are you really going to worry about a sea level rise of 1 inch per decade?”

claim: back in the late 1980s, the un claimed that if global warming were not checked by 2000, rising sea levels would wash entire counties away.

claim: an area of coastal ecosystems larger than new york city is destroyed every year, removing an important buffer from extreme weather for coastal communities and releasing carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
label: supports
evidence: both the decay and the burning of wood release much of this stored carbon back into the atmosphere.

claim: 195 countries signed the 2015 paris agreement, agreeing to limit global warming and adapt to climate change, partly by protecting nature.
label: supports
evidence: the conference negotiated the paris agreement, a global agreement on the reduction of climate change, the text of which represented a consensus of the representatives of the 196 attending parties.

claim: co2 emissions from all commercial operations in 2018 totaled 918 million metric tons—2.4% of global co2 emissions from fossil fuel use.
label: supports
evidence: in 2011, according to the international energy agency, the actual co2 emissions from electricity generation were 67.32 million metric tons, a share of 36.7% of the countries' total co2 emissions from fuel combustion.

claim: flights departing airports in the united states and its territories emitted about one-quarter (24%) of global passenger transport-related co2, two-thirds of which came from domestic flights.
label: supports
evidence: in 1999 the contribution of civil aircraft-in-flight to global co2 emissions was estimated to be around two percent.

claim: the planet's average surface temperature has risen about 1.62 degrees fahrenheit (0.9 degrees celsius) since the late 19th century, a change driven largely by increased carbon dioxide and other human-made emissions into the atmosphere.

evidence: increases in atmospheric concentrations of co 2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases such as methane, nitrous oxide and ozone have correspondingly strengthened their absorption and emission of infrared radiation, causing the rise in average global temperature since the mid-20th century.

claim: the oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of more than 0.4 degrees fahrenheit since 1969.

evidence: these isotope changes occurred due to the release of carbon from the ocean into the atmosphere that led to a temperature increase of 4-8 °c (7-14 °f) at the surface of the ocean.

claim: the greenland and antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass.
label: supports
evidence: from about 11 million years ago to 10 million years ago, the greenland ice sheet was greatly reduced in size.

claim: glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world — including in the alps, himalayas, andes, rockies, alaska and africa.
label: supports
evidence: extensive glaciers are found in antarctica, argentina, chile, canada, alaska, greenland and iceland.

claim: global sea level rose about 8 inches in the last century.
label: supports
evidence: in 2019, a study projected that in low emission scenario, sea level will rise 30 centimeters by 2050 and 69 centimetres by 2100, relatively to the level in 2000.

claim: both the extent and thickness of arctic sea ice has declined rapidly over the last several decades.
label: supports
evidence: the amount of multi-year sea ice in the arctic has declined considerably in recent decades.

claim: the number of record high temperature events in the united states has been increasing, while the number of record low temperature events has been decreasing, since 1950.
label: supports
evidence: in australia, the annual number of hot days (above 35°c) and very hot days (above 40°c) has increased significantly in many areas of the country since 1950.

claim: since the beginning of the industrial revolution, the acidity of surface ocean waters has increased by about 30 percent.13,14

evidence: ocean acidification has increased 26% since the beginning of the industrial era.

claim: this increase is the result of humans emitting more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere and hence more being absorbed into the oceans.
label: supports
evidence: the oceans act as an enormous carbon sink, and have taken up about a third of co 2 emitted by human activity.

claim: the bushfires in australia were caused by arsonists and a series of lightning strikes, not 'climate change'.
label: disputed
evidence: the 2007 kangaroo island bushfires were a series of bushfires caused by lightning strikes on 6 december 2007 on kangaroo island, south australia, resulting in the destruction of 95,000 hectares (230,000 acres) of national park and wilderness protection area.

claim: discovery of massive volcanic co2 emissions discredits global warming theory.
label: supports
evidence: global anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 2010 were equivalent to 49 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide (using the most recent global warming potentials over 100 years from the ar5 report).

claim: etna has already put more than 10,000 times the co2 into the atmosphere than mankind has in our entire time on the earth.
label: refutes
evidence: human activity since the industrial revolution has increased the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, leading to increased radiative forcing from co2, methane, tropospheric ozone, cfcs, and nitrous oxide.

claim: more than 500 scientists and professionals in climate and related fields have sent a 'european climate declaration' to the secretary-general of the united nations.
label: supports
evidence: this scientific opinion is expressed in synthesis reports, by scientific bodies of national or international standing, and by surveys of opinion among climate scientists.

claim: the consensus among scientists and policy-makers is that we’ll pass this point of no return if the global mean temperature rises by more than two degrees celsius.
label: supports
evidence: the current trajectory of global greenhouse gas emissions is not consistent with limiting global warming to below 1.5 or 2 °c, relative to pre-industrial levels.

claim: human-produced carbon might be one of the factors of climate change, but there’s simply no evidence that it is a significant one.
label: refutes
evidence: european science foundation in a 2007 position paper states: there is now convincing evidence that since the industrial revolution, human activities, resulting in increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases have become a major agent of climate change ... on-going and increased efforts to mitigate climate change through reduction in greenhouse gases are therefore crucial.

claim: in no way, shape, or form are humans warming or cooling the planet.
label: refutes
evidence: since the industrial revolution anthropogenic emissions – primarily from use of fossil fuels and deforestation – have rapidly increased its concentration in the atmosphere, leading to global warming.

claim: i think about all the 194 countries that signed onto the paris accord, the u.s. is the one that's leading the world in reducing emissions.
label: refutes
evidence: at the conclusion of cop 21 (the 21st meeting of the conference of the parties, which guides the conference), on 12 december 2015, the final wording of the paris agreement was adopted by consensus by all of the 195 unfccc participating member states and the european union to reduce emissions as part of the method for reducing greenhouse gas.

claim: 18 proxies tell us the world was the same or warmer 1,000 years ago.
label: refutes
evidence: a wide variety of temperature proxies together prove that the 20th century was the hottest recorded in the last 2,000 years.

claim: the human contribution to global warming was about 0.01°c.
label: refutes
evidence: current pledges made as part of the paris agreement would lead to about 3.0 °c of warming at the end of the 21st century, relative to pre-industrial levels.

claim: so that means that probably about half, maybe half of that nine-tenths of the degree of total warming might be caused by greenhouse gases.
label: supports
evidence: the surprising effect of this is that the global warming potential of co is three times that of co 2.

claim: new study confirms evs considerably worse for climate than diesel cars.
label: refutes
evidence: as of 2018[update] the average diesel car has a worse effect on air quality than the average gasoline car but both gasoline and diesel cars pollute more than electric cars.while there are different ways to power cars most rely on gasoline or diesel, and they consume almost a quarter of world oil production as of 2019[update].

claim: the concentration of carbon dioxide in earth’s atmosphere has climbed to a level last seen more than 3 million years ago — before humans even appeared on the rocky ball we call home.
label: supports
evidence: the daily average concentration of atmospheric co 2 at mauna loa observatory first exceeded 400 ppm on 10 may 2013 although this concentration had already been reached in the arctic in june 2012.

claim: sea level rise due to climate change is not going to happen.
label: refutes
evidence: between 1993 and 2017, the global mean sea level rose on average by 3.1 ± 0.3 mm per year, with an acceleration detected as well.

claim: unadjusted data suggests that temperatures in australia have only increased by 0.3 degrees over the past century, not the 1 degree usually claimed.
label: refutes
evidence: "australia's extreme heat is sign of things to come, scientists warn".

claim: climate models have overestimated the amount of global warming and failed to predict what climatologists call the warming ‘hiatus’.
label: supports
evidence: these models predict an upward trend in the global mean surface temperature, with the most rapid increase in temperature being projected for the higher latitudes of the northern hemisphere.

claim: climate scientists say that aspects of the case of hurricane harvey suggest global warming is making a bad situation worse.
label: supports
evidence: the effects of climate change, in combination with the sustained increases in greenhouse gas emissions, have led scientists to characterize it as a climate emergency.

claim: according, again, to the official figures—during this past 10 years, if anything, mean global temperature, average world temperature, has slightly declined.
label: refutes
evidence: the global temperature kept climbing during the decade.

claim: most likely the primary control knob on climate change is the ocean waters and this environment that we live in.
label: supports
evidence: these include processes such as variations in solar radiation, variations in the earth's orbit, variations in the albedo or reflectivity of the continents, atmosphere, and oceans, mountain-building and continental drift and changes in greenhouse gas concentrations.

claim: global warming' is a myth — so say 80 graphs from 58 peer-reviewed scientific papers published in 2017.
label: refutes
evidence: the independent climate change email review report was published on 7 july 2010.

claim: global warming ceased around the end of the twentieth century and was followed (since 1997) by 19 years of stable temperature.
label: refutes
evidence: the average global temperature on earth has increased by about 0.8° celsius (1.4° fahrenheit) since 1880; two-thirds of the warming has occurred since 1975, at a rate of roughly 0.15-0.20 °c per decade.

claim: doubling the concentration of atmospheric co2 from its pre-industrial level, in the absence of other forcings and feedbacks, would likely cause a warming of ~0.3°c to 1.1°c.
label: supports
evidence: the higher co2 levels led to an additional climate warming ranging between 0.1° and 1.5 °c.

claim: more than 100 per cent of the warming over the past century is due to human actions.
label: supports
evidence: the view that human activities are likely responsible for most of the observed increase in global mean temperature ("global warming") since the mid-20th century is an accurate reflection of current scientific thinking.

claim: i would not agree that carbon dioxide is a primary contributor to the global warming that we see.
label: supports
evidence: the global warming observed over the past 50 years is due primarily to human-induced emissions of heat-trapping gases.

claim: the u.s. is shattering high temperature records far more frequently than it is shattering low temperature records.
label: supports
evidence: the highest temperature ever recorded is 112 °f (44.4 °c) in louisville on july 24, 1952, while the lowest is −17 °f (−27.2 °c) in northern floyd county on january 27, 1940.

claim: observations throughout the world make it clear that climate change is occurring, and rigorous scientific research demonstrates that the greenhouse gases emitted by human activities are the primary driver.
label: supports
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: the earth’s climate is changing in response to increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases (ghgs) and particulate matter in the atmosphere, largely as the result of human activities.
label: supports
evidence: the most talked-about applications of these models in recent years have been their use to infer the consequences of increasing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, primarily carbon dioxide (see greenhouse gas).

claim: research has found a human influence on the climate of the past several decades ...
label: supports
evidence: according to the intergovernmental panel on climate change (ipcc), it is "extremely likely" that human influence was the dominant cause of global warming between 1951 and 2010.

claim: the ipcc (2013), usgcrp (2017), and usgcrp (2018) indicate that it is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-twentieth century.
label: supports
evidence: the intergovernmental panel on climate change (ipcc) fifth assessment report concluded, "it is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century".

claim: earth's changing climate is a critical issue and poses the risk of significant environmental, social and economic disruptions around the globe.
label: supports
evidence: the effects of global warming or climate damage include far-reaching and long-lasting changes to the natural environment, to ecosystems and human societies caused directly or indirectly by human emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: human activities (mainly greenhouse-gas emissions) are the dominant cause of the rapid warming since the middle 1900s (ipcc, 2013).
label: supports
evidence: over the last three decades of the twentieth century, gross domestic product per capita and population growth were the main drivers of increases in greenhouse gas emissions.

claim: scientists have known for some time, from multiple lines of evidence, that humans are changing earth’s climate, primarily through greenhouse gas emissions.
label: supports
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: earth’s climate is now changing faster than at any point in the history of modern civilization, primarily as a result of human activities.
label: supports
evidence: in order to constitute the holocene as an extinction event, scientists must determine exactly when anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions began to measurably alter natural atmospheric levels on a global scale, and when these alterations caused changes to global climate.

claim: warming of the climate system is unequivocal, and since the 1950s, many of the observed changes are unprecedented over decades to millennia.
label: supports
evidence: conclusions of ar5 are summarized below: working group i "warming of the climate system is unequivocal, and since the 1950s, many of the observed changes are unprecedented over decades to millennia".

claim: the atmosphere and ocean have warmed, the amounts of snow and ice have diminished, and sea level has risen.
label: supports
evidence: the atmosphere and ocean have warmed, the amounts of snow and ice have diminished, sea level has risen, and the concentrations of greenhouse gases have increased "myths vs. facts: denial of petitions for reconsideration of the endangerment and cause or contribute findings for greenhouse gases under section 202(a) of the clean air act".

claim: climate change is due to cosmic rays.

evidence: the primary goal is to understand the influence of galactic cosmic rays (gcrs) on aerosols and clouds, and their implications for climate.

claim: sea level rise due to global warming is exaggerated.

evidence: between 1993 and 2017, the global mean sea level rose on average by 3.1 ± 0.3 mm per year, with an acceleration detected as well.

claim: arctic icemelt is a natural cycle.
label: refutes

claim: increasing co2 in the atmosphere has little to no effect.

evidence: higher atmospheric co2 concentrations have led to an increase in dissolved co2, which causes ocean acidification.

claim: human co2 is a tiny fraction of co2 emissions.
label: refutes
evidence: human activities emit about 29 billion tons of carbon dioxide per year, while volcanoes emit between 0.2 and 0.3 billion tons.

claim: water vapor is the most powerful greenhouse gas.
label: supports
evidence: natural gas is thus a more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide due to the greater global-warming potential of methane.

claim: polar bear numbers are increasing.
label: refutes

claim: there's no empirical evidence for climate change.
label: refutes
evidence: climate change has proven to affect biodiversity and evidence supporting the altering effects is widespread.

claim: 2009-2010 winter saw record cold spells.
label: supports

claim: climate change is because of el niño.

claim: climate change is because of pacific decadal oscillation.
label: supports
evidence: examples include variability in ocean basins such as the pacific decadal oscillation and atlantic multidecadal oscillation.

claim: clouds provide negative feedback.

label: refutes

claim: they changed the name from 'global warming' to 'climate change'.

claim: ipcc overestimate temperature rise.

claim: sea level rise is decelerating.

claim: humans are too insignificant to affect global climate.
label: refutes

claim: phil jones says no global warming since 1995.

claim: arctic sea ice loss is matched by antarctic sea ice gain.

claim: over 31,000 scientists signed the oism petition project.
label: supports

claim: less than half of published scientists endorse global warming.
label: refutes
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: tuvalu sea level isn't rising.
label: refutes

claim: renewables can't provide baseload power.

claim: ice sheet losses are overestimated.

claim: melting ice isn't warming the arctic.

claim: murry salby finds co2 rise is natural.

claim: 97% consensus on human-caused global warming has been disproven.

evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: water vapor in the stratosphere stopped global warming.
label: supports

claim: adapting to global warming is cheaper than preventing it.
label: disputed
evidence: adaptation is especially important in developing countries since those countries are bearing the brunt of the effects of global warming.

claim: cern cloud experiment proved cosmic rays are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: "sun's shifts may cause global warming".

claim: antarctica is too cold to lose ice.
label: disputed
evidence: offshore, temperatures are also low enough that ice is formed from seawater through most of the year.

claim: coral atolls grow as sea levels rise.
label: supports
evidence: gradual sea-level rise also allows for coral polyp activity to raise the atolls with the sea level.

claim: co2 increase is natural, not human-caused.
label: refutes

claim: scientists retracted claim that sea levels are rising.
label: refutes
evidence: sea level rise will continue over many centuries.

claim: renewable energy investment kills jobs.

claim: greenland has only lost a tiny fraction of its ice mass.

claim: arctic sea ice extent was lower in the past.

claim: climate change isn't increasing extreme weather damage costs.

claim: ipcc human-caused global warming attribution confidence is unfounded.
label: refutes
evidence: there is a clear human influence on the climate it is extremely likely that human influence has been the dominant cause of observed warming since 1950, with the level of confidence having increased since the fourth report.

claim: great barrier reef is in good shape.
label: disputed

claim: global warming is increasing the risk of heatwaves.

claim: climate reacts to whatever forces it to change at the time; humans are now the dominant forcing.
label: supports

claim: in the last 35 years of global warming, sun and climate have been going in opposite directions.
label: supports

claim: 97% of climate experts agree humans are causing global warming.
label: supports
evidence: climate scientists have reached a consensus that the earth is undergoing significant anthropogenic (human-induced) global warming.

claim: the warming trend is the same in rural and urban areas, measured by thermometers and satellites.
label: disputed

claim: satellites measure antarctica losing land ice at an accelerating rate.

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.

claim: most glaciers are retreating, posing a serious problem for millions who rely on glaciers for water.
label: supports
evidence: earth's glaciers are expected to melt within the next forty years, greatly decreasing fresh water flow in the hotter times of the year, causing everyone to depend on rainwater, resulting in large shortages and fluctuations in fresh water availability which largely effects agriculture, power supply, and human health and well-being.
article: effects of global warming on human health

claim: cosmic rays show no trend over the last 30 years & have had little impact on recent global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: in the scientific literature, there is an overwhelming consensus that global surface temperatures have increased in recent decades and that the trend is caused mainly by human-induced emissions of greenhouse gases.

claim: extreme weather events are being made more frequent and worse by global warming.
label: supports
evidence: impacts include the direct effects of extreme weather, leading to injury and loss of life; and indirect effects, such as undernutrition brought on by crop failures.

claim: a variety of different measurements find steadily rising sea levels over the past century.
label: supports
evidence: since at least the start of the 20th century, the average global sea level has been rising.

claim: urban and rural regions show the same warming trend.
label: disputed
evidence: on the other hand, one 1999 comparison between urban and rural areas proposed that urban heat island effects have little influence on global mean temperature trends.

claim: the most recent ocean measurements show consistent warming.
label: supports
evidence: the warming evident in the instrumental temperature record is consistent with a wide range of observations, documented by many independent scientific groups; for example, in most continental regions the frequency and intensity of heavy precipitation has increased.

claim: ancient natural cycles are irrelevant for attributing recent global warming to humans.
label: disputed
evidence: there is a scientific consensus linking human activities to global warming due to industrial carbon dioxide emissions.

claim: the natural cycle adds and removes co2 to keep a balance; humans add extra co2 without removing any.
label: supports
evidence: the co 2 is removed after combustion of fossil fuels, but before the flue gas is expanded to atmospheric pressure.

claim: numerous papers have documented how ipcc predictions are more likely to underestimate the climate response.
label: disputed
evidence: projections based on the special report on emissions scenarios suggest warming over the 21st century at a more rapid rate than that experienced for at least the last 10,000 years.

claim: rising co2 increases atmospheric water vapor, which makes global warming much worse.
label: supports
evidence: increases in atmospheric concentrations of co 2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases such as methane, nitrous oxide and ozone have correspondingly strengthened their absorption and emission of infrared radiation, causing the rise in average global temperature since the mid-20th century.

claim: polar bears are in danger of extinction as well as many other species.
label: supports
evidence: there is widespread consensus among scientists that human activity is accelerating the extinction of many animal species through the destruction of habitats, the consumption of animals as resources, and the elimination of species that humans view as threats or competitors.

claim: greenland on the whole is losing ice, as confirmed by satellite measurement.
label: supports
evidence: these measurements came from the us space agency's grace (gravity recovery and climate experiment) satellite, launched in 2002, as reported by bbc.

claim: the effects of enhanced co2 on terrestrial plants are variable and complex and dependent on numerous factors.
label: supports

claim: thick arctic sea ice is in rapid retreat.
label: supports

claim: there is long-term correlation between co2 and global temperature; other effects are short-term.
label: supports
evidence: gore's use of long ice core records of co2 and temperature (from oxygen isotope measurements) in antarctic ice cores to illustrate the correlation between the two drew some scrutiny; schmidt, steig and michael e. mann back up gore's data.

claim: scientists have determined that the factors which caused the little ice age cooling are not currently causing global warming.
label: supports
evidence: historical patterns of warming and cooling, like the medieval climate anomaly and the little ice age, were not as synchronous as current warming, but may have reached temperatures as high as those of the late-20th century in a limited set of regions.

claim: global temperature is still rising and 2010 was the hottest recorded.
label: supports
evidence: in israel, the year 2010 was the hottest on record, and average temperatures were 2-3 degrees celsius higher than the average.

claim: early 20th century warming is due to several causes, including rising co2.
label: supports
evidence: the largest contribution to total radiative forcing is caused by the increase in the atmospheric concentration of co2 since 1750."

claim: the most recent satellite data show that the earth as a whole is warming.
label: supports
evidence: "evidence is now 'unequivocal' that humans are causing global warming – un report".

claim: a cold day in chicago in winter has nothing to do with the trend of global warming.

claim: no known natural forcing fits the fingerprints of observed warming except anthropogenic greenhouse gases.
label: supports
evidence: attributing detected temperature changes and extreme events to human-caused increases in greenhouse gases requires scientists to rule out known internal climate variability and natural external forcings.

claim: the 2nd law of thermodynamics is consistent with the greenhouse effect which is directly observed.
label: supports
evidence: this does not conflict with notions that have been observed of the fundamental laws of physics, namely cpt symmetry, since the second law applies statistically, it is hypothesized, on time-asymmetric boundary conditions.

claim: weather and climate are different; climate predictions do not need weather detail.
label: refutes
evidence: lorenz's discovery, which gave its name to lorenz attractors, showed that even detailed atmospheric modelling cannot, in general, make precise long-term weather predictions.

claim: those who contribute the least greenhouse gases will be most impacted by climate change.
label: supports
evidence: the largest human influence has been the emission of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide.

claim: evidence is building that net cloud feedback is likely positive and unlikely to be strongly negative.

claim: that human co2 is causing global warming is known with high certainty & confirmed by observations.
label: supports
evidence: attribution of recent climate change is the effort to scientifically ascertain mechanisms responsible for recent global warming and related climate changes on earth.

claim: sea level rise is now increasing faster than predicted due to unexpectedly rapid ice melting.
label: supports
evidence: since the last glacial maximum about 20,000 years ago, the sea level has risen by more than 125 metres (410 ft), with rates varying from less than a mm/year to 40+ mm/year, as a result of melting ice sheets over canada and eurasia.

claim: the oceans are warming and moreover are becoming more acidic, threatening the food chain.
label: supports
evidence: ocean acidification is the ongoing decrease in the ph of the earth's oceans, caused by the uptake of carbon dioxide (co 2) from the atmosphere.

claim: around 97% of climate experts agree that humans are causing global warming.
label: disputed
evidence: climate scientists have reached a consensus that the earth is undergoing significant anthropogenic (human-induced) global warming.

claim: methane plays a minor role in global warming but could get much worse if permafrost starts to melt.
label: supports
evidence: with rising global temperatures, the amount of permafrost melting and releasing methane continues to increase.

claim: there will still be about a million square kilometres of ice in the arctic in summer

claim: “underneath the permafrost there are sediments full of methane hydrates.

claim: “as surface temperatures of the oceans warm up, the immediate response is more water vapor in the atmosphere.

claim: while the north-east, midwest and upper great plains have experienced a 30% increase in heavy rainfall episodes – considered once-in-every-five year downpours – parts of the west, particularly california, have been parched by drought.

claim: greenland ice sheet … would balloon sea levels by around 7m should it disintegrate

claim: cold kills many more people than heat.

claim: cold deaths actually occur during moderate temperatures

claim: until last june, most scientists acknowledged that warming reached a peak in the late 1990s

claim: the strong el niño has continued into 2016, raising the possibility that this year will, yet again, set a global temperature record
label: supports
evidence: despite one of the strongest el nino ever recorded in the pacific ocean, a largely positive north atlantic oscillation prevailed over europe during the winter of 2015-2016.

claim: world temperatures, because they have gone up only very slowly, less than half as fast as the scientific consensus predicted in 1990

claim: antarctica is gaining land-based ice, according to a new study by nasa scientists published in the journal of glaciology

claim: if global warming caused the 2014 queensland heat wave, why wasn’t it as severe as the 1972 queensland heat wave?”

claim: the late 1970s marked the end of a 30-year cooling trend.

claim: in recent decades this warming has been accompanied by a constant rise in the sea level and, it would appear, by an increase of extreme weather events, even if a scientifically determinable cause cannot be assigned to each particular phenomenon.

claim: the melting in the polar ice caps and in high altitude plains can lead to the dangerous release of methane gas

claim: eleven percent of all global greenhouse gas emissions caused by humans are caused by deforestation — comparable to the emissions from all of the cars and trucks on the planet.

claim: 195 countries signed the 2015 paris agreement, agreeing to limit global warming and adapt to climate change, partly by protecting nature.
label: supports

claim: co2 emissions from all commercial operations in 2018 totaled 918 million metric tons—2.4% of global co2 emissions from fossil fuel use.

claim: the oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of more than 0.4 degrees fahrenheit since 1969.

article: effects of global warming on oceans

claim: glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world — including in the alps, himalayas, andes, rockies, alaska and africa.

claim: both the extent and thickness of arctic sea ice has declined rapidly over the last several decades.
label: supports

claim: since the beginning of the industrial revolution, the acidity of surface ocean waters has increased by about 30 percent.13,14

claim: the bushfires in australia were caused by arsonists and a series of lightning strikes, not 'climate change'.

claim: discovery of massive volcanic co2 emissions discredits global warming theory.

claim: human-produced carbon might be one of the factors of climate change, but there’s simply no evidence that it is a significant one.
label: refutes

claim: in no way, shape, or form are humans warming or cooling the planet.
label: refutes
evidence: the current scientific consensus on climate change is that the earth underwent global warming throughout the 20th century and continues to warm.

claim: new study confirms evs considerably worse for climate than diesel cars.

claim: climate scientists say that aspects of the case of hurricane harvey suggest global warming is making a bad situation worse.

claim: according, again, to the official figures—during this past 10 years, if anything, mean global temperature, average world temperature, has slightly declined.

claim: global warming' is a myth — so say 80 graphs from 58 peer-reviewed scientific papers published in 2017.

claim: global warming ceased around the end of the twentieth century and was followed (since 1997) by 19 years of stable temperature.

claim: i would not agree that carbon dioxide is a primary contributor to the global warming that we see.

claim: observations throughout the world make it clear that climate change is occurring, and rigorous scientific research demonstrates that the greenhouse gases emitted by human activities are the primary driver.

claim: the earth’s climate is changing in response to increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases (ghgs) and particulate matter in the atmosphere, largely as the result of human activities.

claim: research has found a human influence on the climate of the past several decades ...
label: supports

claim: warming of the climate system is unequivocal, and since the 1950s, many of the observed changes are unprecedented over decades to millennia.

claim: the atmosphere and ocean have warmed, the amounts of snow and ice have diminished, and sea level has risen.

claim: increasing co2 in the atmosphere has little to no effect.

claim: polar bear numbers are increasing.

claim: climate change is because of pacific decadal oscillation.

claim: al gore's book is quite accurate, and far more accurate than contrarian books.

claim: natural cycles superimposed on a linear warming trend can be mistaken for step changes, but the underlying warming is caused by the external radiative forcing.

claim: a few degrees of global warming has a huge impact on ice sheets, sea levels and other aspects of climate.

claim: the ipcc 95% confidence that humans are responsible for most of the current global warming is simply a summary of the peer-reviewed scientific research.

claim: co2 emissions were much smaller 100 years ago.

claim: carbon dioxide is not "a primary contributor to the global warming that we see."

claim: in reality, gas produced by fracking is worse for the climate than coal.

claim: in south florida, "we've had nine inches of sea-level rise since the 1920s."

claim: nasa finds antarctica is gaining ice,

claim: global warming is an increasingly urgent problem.
label: supports
evidence: people who regard climate change as catastrophic, irreversible, or rapid might label climate change as a climate crisis or a climate emergency.

claim: global brightening is caused by changes in cloud cover, reflective aerosols and absorbing aerosols.
label: disputed
evidence: aerosols and other particulates absorb solar energy and reflect sunlight back into space.

claim: satellites confirmed measurements from ground stations show a considerable, and naturally-occurring, global brightening from 1983-2001 (pinker et al., 2005).
label: supports
evidence: there was solar brightening beyond 2000 at numerous stations in europe, the united states, and korea.

claim: the petition project features over 31,000 scientists signing the petition stating "there is no convincing scientific evidence that human release of carbon dioxide will, in the forseeable future, cause catastrophic heating of the earth's atmosphere".
label: disputed
evidence: 7–10 "there is now convincing evidence that since the industrial revolution, human activities, resulting in increasing concentrations of greenhouse gases have become a major agent of climate change.

claim: the fact that so many studies on climate change don't bother to endorse the consensus position is significant because scientists have largely moved from what's causing global warming onto discussing details of the problem (eg - how fast, how soon, impacts, etc).
label: supports
evidence: there is an extensive discussion in the scientific literature on what policies might be effective in responding to climate change.

claim: when stomata-derived co2 (red) is compared to ice core-derived co2 (blue), the stomata generally show much more variability in the atmospheric co2 level and often show levels much higher than the ice cores.
label: supports
evidence: the proportions of different oxygen and hydrogen isotopes provide information about ancient temperatures, and the air trapped in tiny bubbles can be analysed to determine the level of atmospheric gases such as carbon dioxide.

claim: arctic summer sea ice has shrunk by an area equal to western australia, and might be all gone in a decade.
label: refutes
evidence: the summer shrinking of the ice has been quoted at 50%.

claim: thanks to a rapid rebound in recent months, global sea ice levels now equal those seen 29 years ago, when the year 1979 also drew to a close.
label: disputed
evidence: thus global sea level fell during glaciation.

claim: the data is being reported by the university of illinois's arctic climate research center, and is derived from satellite observations of the northern and southern hemisphere polar regions (daily tech).
label: supports
evidence: it was developed completely from surface-based weather observations, including descriptions of clouds found near frontal boundaries.

claim: the exception to this ice loss is antarctic sea ice which has been growing despite the warming southern ocean.
label: supports
evidence: since the ocean off the antarctic coast usually is much warmer than the air over it, the extent of the sea ice is largely controlled by the winds and currents that push it northwards.

claim: the claim sea level isn’t rising is based on blatantly doctored graphs and conspiracy theories that are contradicted by empirical observational data.
label: supports
evidence: both natural and social sciences are empirical sciences as their knowledge are based on empirical observations and are capable of being tested for its validity by other researchers working under the same conditions.

claim: "by the 2001 [ipcc] climate assessment...the medieval warm period had been ingeniously wiped out.
label: supports
evidence: this graph extended the similar graph in figure 3.20 from the ipcc second assessment report of 1995, and differed from a schematic in the first assessment report that lacked temperature units, but appeared to depict larger global temperature variations over the past 1000 years, and higher temperatures during the medieval warm period than the mid 20th century.

claim: weather is chaotic because air is light, it has low friction and viscosity, it expands strongly when in contact with hot surfaces and it conducts heat poorly.
label: supports
evidence: liquids tend to have better thermal conductivity than gases, and the ability to flow makes a liquid suitable for removing excess heat from mechanical components.

claim: skeptics who oppose scientific findings that threaten their world view are far closer to galileo's belief-based critics in the catholic church.
label: supports
evidence: an alternative criticism is that the church opposed particular scientific discoveries that it felt challenged its authority and power – particularly through the reformation and on through the enlightenment.

claim: science entitled the scientific consensus on climate change (oreskes 2004).
label: supports
evidence: in 2004, the geologist and historian of science naomi oreskes summarized a study of the scientific literature on climate change.

claim: the report suggests significantly smaller overall  ice-mass losses than previous estimates.
label: refutes
evidence: as with glaciers worldwide, those of the greater himalayan region are experiencing a decline in mass, and researchers claim that between the early 1970s and early 2000s, there had been a 9 percent reduction in ice mass.

claim: "so  recently the media picked up on the fact that cru deleted the raw data for this  important global temperature set long ago.
label: refutes
evidence: on 27 july 2011 cru announced release of the raw instrumental data not already in the public domain, with the exception of poland which was outside the area covered by the foia request.

claim: maximum warming occurs over the surface during winter while less surface warming is found in summer when heat is being used to melt sea ice.
label: supports
evidence: in summer, the sea ice keeps the surface from warming above freezing.

claim: whatever is driving increases in winter arctic temperatures   is not heat coming out of the arctic ocean, which is covered with   insulating ice.'
label: disputed
evidence: this insulation keeps the warm atlantic water from melting the surface ice.

claim: if senator wong was really serious about her  science she would stop breathing because you inhale air that's got 385  parts per million carbon dioxide in it
label: refutes
evidence: excluding water vapor, about half of landfill gas is methane and most of the rest is carbon dioxide, with small amounts of nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen, and variable trace amounts of hydrogen sulfide and siloxanes.

claim: the long-term correlation between co2 and temperature is well established.
label: disputed
evidence: "coherence established between atmospheric carbon dioxide and global temperature".

claim: co2 changes are closely related to temperature.
label: supports
evidence: these three changes are closely interrelated, because venus's extreme temperature is due to the high pressure of its dense atmosphere, and the greenhouse effect.

claim: warmer seasons or triennial phases are followed by an atmosphere that is rich in co2, reflecting the gas solving or exsolving from water, and not photosynthesis activity.
label: supports
evidence: higher atmospheric co2 concentrations have led to an increase in dissolved co2, which causes ocean acidification.

claim: various independent measurements of solar activity all confirm the sun has shown a slight cooling trend since 1978.
label: supports
evidence: in the three decades following 1978, the combination of solar and volcanic activity is estimated to have had a slight cooling influence.

claim: cooks ’97% consensus’ disproven by a new peer
label: refutes
evidence: of these, 97% agree, explicitly or implicitly, that global warming is happening and is human-caused.

claim: when co2 emissions are compared directly to co2 levels, there is a strong correlation in the long term trends.
label: supports
evidence: further research has demonstrated a reliable correlation between co 2 levels and the temperature calculated from ice isotope data.

claim: "global warming is mostly due to heat production by human industry since the 1800s, from nuclear power and fossil fuels, better termed hydrocarbons, – coal, oil, natural gas.
label: supports
evidence: at present, the primary source of co 2 emissions is the burning of coal, natural gas, and petroleum for electricity and heat.

claim: statistical analysis of the rate of warming over different periods find that warming from 1970 to 2001 is greater than the warming from both 1860 to 1880 and 1910 to 1940.
label: supports
evidence: multiple independently produced instrumental datasets confirm that the 2009–2018 decade was 0.93 ± 0.07 °c warmer than the pre-industrial baseline (1850–1900).

claim: despite the logarithmic relationship between co2 and surface temperatures, atmospheric co2 levels are rising so fast that unless we dramatically decrease our emissions, global warming will accelerate over the 21st century.
label: supports
evidence: increases in atmospheric concentrations of co 2 and other long-lived greenhouse gases such as methane, nitrous oxide and ozone have correspondingly strengthened their absorption and emission of infrared radiation, causing the rise in average global temperature since the mid-20th century.

claim: as a result, the planet as a whole is becoming less reflective and absorbing more sunlight, which is accelerating global warming.
label: supports
evidence: not only does this increase the absorption of sunlight, it also increases melting and sea level rise.

claim: the measurements of the amount of co2 made at the mauna loa observatory are accurate and uncontaminated by any emissions from the volcano.
label: supports
evidence: since 1958, initially under the direction of charles keeling, followed by his son ralph and later elmer robinson, mauna loa observatory (mlo) has been monitoring and collecting data relating to atmospheric change, and is known especially for the continuous monitoring of atmospheric carbon dioxide (co2), which is sometimes referred to as the keeling curve.

claim: venus is not hot because of a runaway greenhouse.
label: refutes
evidence: he also perceived global warming as a growing, man-made danger and likened it to the natural development of venus into a hot, life-hostile planet through a kind of runaway greenhouse effect.

claim: however, more direct comparisons between solar activity and global temperature finds that  as the sun grew hotter or cooler, earth's climate followed it with a 10 year lag - presumably due to the dampening effect of the ocean.
label: refutes
evidence: another line of evidence for the warming not being due to the sun is how temperature changes differ at different levels in the earth's atmosphere.

claim: consequently, co2 levels at around 1,000 to 2,300 ppm were actually low enough to promote glaciation in the southern continent of gondwana.
label: supports
evidence: decreasing co 2 concentration, with a tipping point of 600 ppm, was the primary agent forcing antarctic glaciation.

claim: clearly, other factors besides atmospheric carbon influence earth temperatures and global warming."
label: supports
evidence: it is expected that most ecosystems will be affected by higher atmospheric co2 levels and higher global temperatures.

claim: this increases confidence in other peer-reviewed research predicting sea level rise of 80cm to 2 metres by 2100.
label: supports
evidence: however, greg holland from the national center for atmospheric research, who reviewed the study, noted: “there is no doubt that the sea level rise, within the ipcc, is a very conservative number, so the truth lies somewhere between ipcc and jim.” in addition, one 2017 study's scenario, assuming high fossil fuel use for combustion and strong economic growth during this century, projects sea level rise of up to 132 cm (4.3 ft) on average — and an extreme scenario with as much as 189 cm (6.2 ft), by 2100.

claim: "a paper...in science magazine concludes that the climate sensitivity—how much the earth’s average temperature will rise as a result of a doubling of the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide—likely (that is, with a 66% probability) lies in the range 1.7°c to 2.6°c, with a median value of 2.3°c.
label: disputed
evidence: the equilibrium climate sensitivity (ecs) is the temperature increase that would result from sustained doubling of the concentration of carbon dioxide in earth's atmosphere, after the earth's energy budget and the climate system reach radiative equilibrium.

claim: "the temperature increase in the second half of the 20th century could have taken place in steps driven by major enso events" (jens raunsø jensen)
label: disputed
evidence: for example, one of the most recent results, even after subtracting the positive influence of decadal variation, is shown to be possibly present in the enso trend, the amplitude of the enso variability in the observed data still increases, by as much as 60% in the last 50 years.

claim: "disasters cost more than ever — but not because of climate change" (roger pielke jr.)
label: refutes
evidence: it would be cheaper, they say, to wait for the impacts of climate change and then adapt to them" says writer and environmental activist george monbiot in an article addressing the supposed economic hazards of addressing climate change.

claim: "cloud cover in models is poorly treated and inaccurately predicted.
label: supports
evidence: leading global models produce quite different results, however, with some showing increasing low clouds and others showing decreases.

claim: given that a doubling of carbon dioxide would change the surface heat flux by only two watts per square meter, it is evident that a small change in cloud cover can strongly affect the response to carbon dioxide."
label: supports
evidence: a typical value of λ, 0.8 k/(w/m2), gives an increase in global temperature of about 1.6 k above the 1750 reference temperature due to the increase in co 2 over that time (278 to 405 ppm, for a forcing of 2.0 w/m2), and predicts a further warming of 1.4 k above present temperatures if the co 2 mixing ratio in the atmosphere were to become double its pre-industrial value; both of these calculations assume no other forcings.

claim: the great barrier reef is in fine fettle
label: refutes
evidence: when queensland edged into tropical waters 24 million years ago, some coral grew, but a sedimentation regime quickly developed with erosion of the great dividing range; creating river deltas, oozes and turbidites, unsuitable conditions for coral growth.

claim: "there are other possible causes for climate change which could be associated with solar activity or related to variations in the temperature of the liquid core of the earth, which is about 5,400 degrees celsius.
label: supports
evidence: at the center, the temperature may be up to 6,000 °c (10,830 °f), and the pressure could reach 360 gpa (52 million psi).

claim: over the last decade, heatwaves are five times more likely than if there had been no global warming.
label: supports
evidence: australia's climate has warmed by more than one degree celsius over the past century, causing an increase in the frequency and intensity of heatwaves and droughts.
